values.description:
This pull request includes a functional Fourier basis for use as the primary/tau basis, with real and complex transforms provided by scipy.  

It also includes Fourier versions of the CGLE, heat, and wave tests.  The linear (wave & heat) tests seem to give the correct results, but the results of the CGLE test need to be investigated (i.e. the initial conditions might need to be changed, or there may be issues with dealiasing, etc).
values.title: Add Fourier Tau basis

summary.raw:
This pull request includes a functional Fourier basis for use as the primary/tau basis, with real and complex transforms provided by scipy.  

It also includes Fourier versions of the CGLE, heat, and wave tests.  The linear (wave & heat) tests seem to give the correct results, but the results of the CGLE test need to be investigated (i.e. the initial conditions might need to be changed, or there may be issues with dealiasing, etc).
summary.html:
This pull request includes a functional Fourier basis for use as the primary/tau basis, with real and complex transforms provided by scipy.

It also includes Fourier versions of the CGLE, heat, and wave tests. The linear (wave & heat) tests seem to give the correct results, but the results of the CGLE test need to be investigated (i.e. the initial conditions might need to be changed, or there may be issues with dealiasing, etc).

values.description:
Many changes, most notably including the framework for adding an arbitrary number of transverse Fourier dimensions to the domain.  

Multidimensional tests are included, and the 1D tests have been updated as needed.
values.title: Multi-dimensional implementation.

values.description: This pull request implements a new system of representing spectral spaces (layout objects) and uses MPI and FFTW to parallelize N-dimensional problems over up-to-(N-1)-dimensional process grids.
values.title: MPI & FFTW Parallelization

summary.raw: This pull request implements a new system of representing spectral spaces (layout objects) and uses MPI and FFTW to parallelize N-dimensional problems over up-to-(N-1)-dimensional process grids.
summary.html: This pull request implements a new system of representing spectral spaces (layout objects) and uses MPI and FFTW to parallelize N-dimensional problems over up-to-(N-1)-dimensional process grids.

values.description:
Major new features:

* Arbitrary dealiasing for Fourier and Chebyshev basis, handled in a memory efficient manner by performing local copies into transform buffers to add and excise padding before and after transforms.

* Add logging and config system

Major implementation changes:

* Pencil matrix construction has been redone, substantially decreasing instantiation time on large/3D problems

* A multiple-dispatch metaclass has been implemented in the operators module to most efficiently deal with field operations involving scalars vs other fields

* Tools have been broken out by type, and the FFTW wrappers/interface has been moved to a 'libraries' sub package.

In addition, a large amount of documentation has been added explaining how to interact with the most important objects/classes, as well as giving some insight into implementation details, etc.

(*Edited for formatting*)
values.title: Dealiasing, logging/config, documentation

summary.raw:
Major new features:

* Arbitrary dealiasing for Fourier and Chebyshev basis, handled in a memory efficient manner by performing local copies into transform buffers to add and excise padding before and after transforms.

* Add logging and config system

Major implementation changes:

* Pencil matrix construction has been redone, substantially decreasing instantiation time on large/3D problems

* A multiple-dispatch metaclass has been implemented in the operators module to most efficiently deal with field operations involving scalars vs other fields

* Tools have been broken out by type, and the FFTW wrappers/interface has been moved to a 'libraries' sub package.

In addition, a large amount of documentation has been added explaining how to interact with the most important objects/classes, as well as giving some insight into implementation details, etc.

(*Edited for formatting*)
summary.html:
Major new features:

  • Arbitrary dealiasing for Fourier and Chebyshev basis, handled in a memory efficient manner by performing local copies into transform buffers to add and excise padding before and after transforms.

  • Add logging and config system

Major implementation changes:

  • Pencil matrix construction has been redone, substantially decreasing instantiation time on large/3D problems

  • A multiple-dispatch metaclass has been implemented in the operators module to most efficiently deal with field operations involving scalars vs other fields

  • Tools have been broken out by type, and the FFTW wrappers/interface has been moved to a 'libraries' sub package.

In addition, a large amount of documentation has been added explaining how to interact with the most important objects/classes, as well as giving some insight into implementation details, etc.

(Edited for formatting)

values.description: This PR introduces a new Problem class that parses full equations and boundary conditions.  It also reworks much of the PDE structure to include selection matrices, allowing both equations and BCs to be changed between pencils.
values.title: ParsedProblems and automatic NCC expansion

summary.raw: This PR introduces a new Problem class that parses full equations and boundary conditions.  It also reworks much of the PDE structure to include selection matrices, allowing both equations and BCs to be changed between pencils.
summary.html: This PR introduces a new Problem class that parses full equations and boundary conditions. It also reworks much of the PDE structure to include selection matrices, allowing both equations and BCs to be changed between pencils.

values.description: The nonlinear-evaluation is replaced with an Evaluator system that allows the attachment of handlers with associated operator trees/tasks.  Handlers are used to compute the RHS terms, as well as analysis terms in a coordinated fashion.  The analysis handlers use parallel-hdf5 to jointly write to single files.  Finally field.constant metadata has been added to track when a field is really defined over the subspace of the domain, and correspondingly just the relevant data is saved.  Integration and interpolation basis methods and operators are implemented.
values.title: Analysis + Joint Evaluator

summary.raw: The nonlinear-evaluation is replaced with an Evaluator system that allows the attachment of handlers with associated operator trees/tasks.  Handlers are used to compute the RHS terms, as well as analysis terms in a coordinated fashion.  The analysis handlers use parallel-hdf5 to jointly write to single files.  Finally field.constant metadata has been added to track when a field is really defined over the subspace of the domain, and correspondingly just the relevant data is saved.  Integration and interpolation basis methods and operators are implemented.
summary.html: The nonlinear-evaluation is replaced with an Evaluator system that allows the attachment of handlers with associated operator trees/tasks. Handlers are used to compute the RHS terms, as well as analysis terms in a coordinated fashion. The analysis handlers use parallel-hdf5 to jointly write to single files. Finally field.constant metadata has been added to track when a field is really defined over the subspace of the domain, and correspondingly just the relevant data is saved. Integration and interpolation basis methods and operators are implemented.

values.description:
1) The solver/timestepper divide has been reorganized to accomodate non-multistep methods.  The remaining variable-step-size multistep IMEX schemes from Wang 2008 have been implemented, along with a few IMEX Runge-Kutta methods from Ascher 1997.

2) Operators wrapping many numpy unary ufuncs, and generic function/arg sets, have been added.

3) Writing through h5py has been modified to use the low-level interface so that collective calls can be issued for data, including subspace data.

4) Several convenience functions have been added for the parallelized post-processing of hdf5 datasets.

5) A DictionaryHandler has been added based on the CalculationHandler from Daniel's branch, which is convenient for e.g. cfl calculations.

6) The existing FFTW transform wrappers have incorporated into the bases/distributor.  Using FFTW transforms is now a config option, default True.

7) Config options have also been added for scipy.linalg.sparse.spsolve options.

8) A simple, optional, length-1 cache has been added for saving operator outputs.  It's enabled by default just for integrate and interpolate operators, to try to balance memory consumption vs. performance.
values.title: Expanded timesteppers, low-level h5py, FFTW transforms

summary.raw:
1) The solver/timestepper divide has been reorganized to accomodate non-multistep methods.  The remaining variable-step-size multistep IMEX schemes from Wang 2008 have been implemented, along with a few IMEX Runge-Kutta methods from Ascher 1997.

2) Operators wrapping many numpy unary ufuncs, and generic function/arg sets, have been added.

3) Writing through h5py has been modified to use the low-level interface so that collective calls can be issued for data, including subspace data.

4) Several convenience functions have been added for the parallelized post-processing of hdf5 datasets.

5) A DictionaryHandler has been added based on the CalculationHandler from Daniel's branch, which is convenient for e.g. cfl calculations.

6) The existing FFTW transform wrappers have incorporated into the bases/distributor.  Using FFTW transforms is now a config option, default True.

7) Config options have also been added for scipy.linalg.sparse.spsolve options.

8) A simple, optional, length-1 cache has been added for saving operator outputs.  It's enabled by default just for integrate and interpolate operators, to try to balance memory consumption vs. performance.
summary.html:
1) The solver/timestepper divide has been reorganized to accomodate non-multistep methods. The remaining variable-step-size multistep IMEX schemes from Wang 2008 have been implemented, along with a few IMEX Runge-Kutta methods from Ascher 1997.

2) Operators wrapping many numpy unary ufuncs, and generic function/arg sets, have been added.

3) Writing through h5py has been modified to use the low-level interface so that collective calls can be issued for data, including subspace data.

4) Several convenience functions have been added for the parallelized post-processing of hdf5 datasets.

5) A DictionaryHandler has been added based on the CalculationHandler from Daniel's branch, which is convenient for e.g. cfl calculations.

6) The existing FFTW transform wrappers have incorporated into the bases/distributor. Using FFTW transforms is now a config option, default True.

7) Config options have also been added for scipy.linalg.sparse.spsolve options.

8) A simple, optional, length-1 cache has been added for saving operator outputs. It's enabled by default just for integrate and interpolate operators, to try to balance memory consumption vs. performance.

values.description:
This pull request includes three distinct changes:

Eigenvalue solver:
This is WIP.  It solved for eigenvalues by making a dense matrix from our problem, under the substitution dt -> -i omega.  This should be cleaned up to probably substitute dt -> gamma, and then sort the eigenvalues, as most of the eigenvalues are going to be either nan's or inf's because our M matrix is singular.

Antidifferentiate methods:
The inverse of the differentiate method.  You can specify a boundary condition: either the function is zero on the left or zero on the right.

Mid-domain BC:
This is WIP.  I tried to set a boundary condition in the middle of the domain.  I think this is implemented correctly, but when I tested it, I got non-sense after a single iteration.  So more testing is needed on this feature.

Bug fix:
I think I fixed a bug in the boundary value problem evaluation logic.  I think the evaluator has changed since BVP was written, so you needed to give a bit more information to the evaluator.
values.title: WIP: Eigenvalue solver; antidifferentiate methods; mid-domain BC

values.description:
This pull includes changes that update the post-processing tools to the new hdf5 file format.  The two major functions are:

1) A set of functions to join distributed analysis files, for easier post-processing.  Usage: e.g.
    dedalus2.tools.post.merge_analysis("snapshots")

2) A set of functions for performing parallelized post-processing on joint datasets.  Basically the writes from any set of specified analysis files are distributed amongst all the available MPI processes, and these chunks are then passed to an arbitrary processing function (e.g. a plotting function).  Usage: e.g.
    dedalus2.tools.post.visit("snapshots/*.h5", my_plotting_function)
values.title: Updated post-processing tools

Basically the writes from any set of specified analysis files are distributed amongst all the available MPI processes, and these chunks are then passed to an arbitrary processing function (e.g. a plotting function).  Usage: e.g.

summary.html:
This pull includes changes that update the post-processing tools to the new hdf5 file format. The two major functions are:

1) A set of functions to join distributed analysis files, for easier post-processing. Usage: e.g. dedalus2.tools.post.merge_analysis("snapshots")

2) A set of functions for performing parallelized post-processing on joint datasets. Basically the writes from any set of specified analysis files are distributed amongst all the available MPI processes, and these chunks are then passed to an arbitrary processing function (e.g. a plotting function). Usage: e.g. dedalus2.tools.post.visit("snapshots/*.h5", my_plotting_function)

values.description: Implements a matrix-solve-based anti differentiation method on the Field class, handling any implicitly defined boundary conditions and inhomogeneous RHSs.
values.title: Implicit antidifferentiation method

summary.raw: Implements a matrix-solve-based anti differentiation method on the Field class, handling any implicitly defined boundary conditions and inhomogeneous RHSs.
summary.html: Implements a matrix-solve-based anti differentiation method on the Field class, handling any implicitly defined boundary conditions and inhomogeneous RHSs.

values.description:
This pull includes:

- Change to standard library-based approach to logging (module-based logging, rather than a sharing application logger)
- Replacing the self-overwritting progress bar with a log-based progress tracker for pencil construction
- Updated requirements file
- Updated setup file that records the mercurial changset ID and diff when the cython build is ran
- Change the post-processing visit function to take a list of filenames rather than a glob pattern, giving more user flexibility on the bash side

Relevant script changes for users:

- Scripts should get a logger using "import logging; logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)" instead of through dedalus2.tools.logging
- Change their post-processing scripts to use the new visit approach
values.title: A collection of small usability changes

summary.raw:
This pull includes:

- Change to standard library-based approach to logging (module-based logging, rather than a sharing application logger)
- Replacing the self-overwritting progress bar with a log-based progress tracker for pencil construction
- Updated requirements file
- Updated setup file that records the mercurial changset ID and diff when the cython build is ran
- Change the post-processing visit function to take a list of filenames rather than a glob pattern, giving more user flexibility on the bash side

Relevant script changes for users:

- Scripts should get a logger using "import logging; logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)" instead of through dedalus2.tools.logging
- Change their post-processing scripts to use the new visit approach
summary.html:
This pull includes:

  • Change to standard library-based approach to logging (module-based logging, rather than a sharing application logger)
  • Replacing the self-overwritting progress bar with a log-based progress tracker for pencil construction
  • Updated requirements file
  • Updated setup file that records the mercurial changset ID and diff when the cython build is ran
  • Change the post-processing visit function to take a list of filenames rather than a glob pattern, giving more user flexibility on the bash side

Relevant script changes for users:

  • Scripts should get a logger using "import logging; logger = logging.getLogger(name)" instead of through dedalus2.tools.logging
  • Change their post-processing scripts to use the new visit approach

values.description:
This install script is based heavily on the yt install script. It is designed to make the full stack required for running Dedalus in parallel on a variety of machines. It is *not* designed to provide the absolute fastest performance possible. My goal with this is to help new users get started, especially on small machines like laptops and desktops. For supercomputing centers and larger high-performance clusters, we should probably continue to update the directions on the website.

It works by first detecting the running operating system, then prompting the user to install several prerequisite packages, either by the system's package manager (if on linux), or manually (if on OSX). Once the user has done this, hitting enter will cause the script to download, from dedalus-project.org, the required software stack, including openmpi (if necessary), python, numpy, scipy, FFTW, HDF5 (if necessary), and freetype (if necessary). After installing all of these packages, the scrip then pip installs nose, mpi4py, h5py, cython, matplotlib, sympy, and optionally ipython. The script does not rely on homebrew for OS X. If you're on OS X, this will also include an OpenMPI install. If you're on linux, we assume you've installed OpenMPI via your package manager.

After the install script successfully completes, the user then enters

$ source path/to/dedalus_x86-64/bin/activate

and, just as in virtualenv, you are in an environment that includes a python3 with dedalus ready to go.
I've tested it on two Ubuntu 14.04 systems (including that the required packages are complete if you have a totally fresh installation), and one OS X 10.8.5 system. However, I have not completed the script for any linux distribution other than Ubuntu (Red Hat, Debian, OpenSUSE, etc), though stubs are in there. I should note that all this means is that the script will not correctly tell you what packages to install. If you have them installed, it should *work* just fine.


To test it, please download

https://bitbucket.org/jsoishi/dedalus2-jsoishi/raw/e711c6f393b37bd0028010c55d212fd4492961b3/docs/install.sh

to somewhere you'd like to install Dedalus, and do

$ bash install.sh

The install it makes will be completely self-contained, so you can just delete the directory it makes, and everything will be back the way you were before.
values.title: [WIP] install script

It works by first detecting the running operating system, then prompting the user to install several prerequisite packages, either by the system's package manager (if on linux), or manually (if on OSX). Once the user has done this, hitting enter will cause the script to download, from dedalus-project.org, the required software stack, including openmpi (if necessary), python, numpy, scipy, FFTW, HDF5 (if necessary), and freetype (if necessary). After installing all of these packages, the scrip then pip installs nose, mpi4py, h5py, cython, matplotlib, sympy, and optionally ipython. The script does not rely on homebrew for OS X. If you're on OS X, this will also include an OpenMPI install. If you're on linux, we assume you've installed OpenMPI via your package manager.

After the install script successfully completes, the user then enters

$ source path/to/dedalus_x86-64/bin/activate

and, just as in virtualenv, you are in an environment that includes a python3 with dedalus ready to go. I've tested it on two Ubuntu 14.04 systems (including that the required packages are complete if you have a totally fresh installation), and one OS X 10.8.5 system. However, I have not completed the script for any linux distribution other than Ubuntu (Red Hat, Debian, OpenSUSE, etc), though stubs are in there. I should note that all this means is that the script will not correctly tell you what packages to install. If you have them installed, it should work just fine.

To test it, please download

https://bitbucket.org/jsoishi/dedalus2-jsoishi/raw/e711c6f393b37bd0028010c55d212fd4492961b3/docs/install.sh

to somewhere you'd like to install Dedalus, and do

$ bash install.sh

The install it makes will be completely self-contained, so you can just delete the directory it makes, and everything will be back the way you were before.

values.description: This pull request merges two working examples (1D KdV Burgers, 2D Rayleigh-Benard) into the main repository.  The purpose is to create a (probably small) set of examples that are included and updated along with the source.  In choosing additional examples to include here, I think we should emphasize demonstrating different aspects of functionality rather than just adding different equations / systems.
values.title: Merge working examples into main repository

values.description:
This pull request generalizes the classes for computing flow properties and CFL.  

The flow properties are generalized to take arbitrary strings (-> operator trees), and the corresponding global min, max, and grid averages are computed and accessed using the property name.  An additional method has been added for computing the volume average of a flow property.

The CFL class is generalized to accept arbitrary frequencies, velocities along any axis, and sets of velocities for use in computing a limiting timestep.  Additionally it allows you to easily add constraints on the max/min timestep and max/min timestep ratio (compared to previous timestep).  The limiting timestep is still computed as the inverse of the global maximum of the sum of the provided frequencies on the dealiased grid.

The RB example has been updated to show how to use both of these new features.
values.title: Flow tools generalization

Additionally it allows you to easily add constraints on the max/min timestep and max/min timestep ratio (compared to previous timestep). The flow properties are generalized to take arbitrary strings (-> operator trees), and the corresponding global min, max, and grid averages are computed and accessed using the property name. An additional method has been added for computing the volume average of a flow property.

The CFL class is generalized to accept arbitrary frequencies, velocities along any axis, and sets of velocities for use in computing a limiting timestep. The RB example has been updated to show how to use both of these new features.

values.description:
Major pull request including largescale implementation changes to the bases and operators.  Main feature changes that affect users are outlined below:

Additions:

* SinCos parity basis

* Nonlinear BVP solver

* Hilbert transform operator

* MPI Alltoallv-based distributed transposes

* Many parsing additions

    * Substitution rules for text-replacement

    * Fields as NCCs

    * Compound derivatives, i.e. "d(u, x=5)"

* Tolerance-based NCC expansions

Changes:

* Dropping the "2" from the package name

* Move default config file to package level

* Basis objects require names on instantiation

* Problem objects require domain on instantiation

* Solver objects are obtained from problem method, not by direct instantiation

Removals:

* No more sympy dependency: all parsing done though operator trees

* basis.grid-shaped arrays no longer allowed as NCCs.  Use fields instead.

Examples have been updated and extended.
values.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

values.description:
This is a work-in-progress pull request to add checkpointing and restart capability to Dedlus IVP problems.  My goal is to streamline the process of restarting simulations.

Right now, I've tested this on 2-D problems at fixed resolution, and we correctly determine a functional (though not exactly identical) CFL timestep on restart.  I'm working on variable resolution restart (hooks are in place, but not clear if they work) as the next step.

This needs example problems that utilize the checkpointing.  Here is an example:

establish saved checkpointing during normal runs:

    from dedalus.extras.checkpointing import Checkpoint
    checkpoint = Checkpoint(data_dir)
    checkpoint.set_checkpoint(solver, iter=20)

Restart from specified (joined) checkpoint ('checkpoint_s5.h5'):

    checkpoint_file = data_dir+'checkpoint/checkpoint_s5.h5'
    checkpoint.restart(checkpoint_file, solver)

All comments welcome.
values.title: [WIP] Checkpointing and restart capability

values.reason: Declining in favor of better implementation by @jsoishi (PR #35).

values.description:
This pull request adds a simple right-preconditioner representing a Dirichlet basis recombination for the Chebyshev basis, making the LHS matrices fully banded for Dirichlet boundary conditions.

~~Extension to compound Chebyshev bases is WIP.~~

Also included is a threshold option for the CFL class, which will only change the timestep for a sufficiently large fractional change, so that small CFL changes don't trigger new matrix factorizations, etc.
values.title: Dirichlet preconditioning

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a simple right-preconditioner representing a Dirichlet basis recombination for the Chebyshev basis, making the LHS matrices fully banded for Dirichlet boundary conditions.

~~Extension to compound Chebyshev bases is WIP.~~

Also included is a threshold option for the CFL class, which will only change the timestep for a sufficiently large fractional change, so that small CFL changes don't trigger new matrix factorizations, etc.
summary.html:
This pull request adds a simple right-preconditioner representing a Dirichlet basis recombination for the Chebyshev basis, making the LHS matrices fully banded for Dirichlet boundary conditions.

Extension to compound Chebyshev bases is WIP.

Also included is a threshold option for the CFL class, which will only change the timestep for a sufficiently large fractional change, so that small CFL changes don't trigger new matrix factorizations, etc.

values.description:
Expands EVP functionality through adding flexibility to the determination of homogeneity (allows for NCCs which add to zero to be considered homogeneous)

*  Introduces ProblemBase._check_if_zero() and ProblemBase._find_max_param(), which together determine if an expression is zero within a tolerance.
*  Modifies ProblemBase._require_homogeneous() to use these new functions rather than only checking if an expression is exactly zero.
values.title: Allows for homogeneous expressions (beyond "0") on RHS of EVP

summary.raw:
Expands EVP functionality through adding flexibility to the determination of homogeneity (allows for NCCs which add to zero to be considered homogeneous)

*  Introduces ProblemBase._check_if_zero() and ProblemBase._find_max_param(), which together determine if an expression is zero within a tolerance.
*  Modifies ProblemBase._require_homogeneous() to use these new functions rather than only checking if an expression is exactly zero.
summary.html:
Expands EVP functionality through adding flexibility to the determination of homogeneity (allows for NCCs which add to zero to be considered homogeneous)

  • Introduces ProblemBase._check_if_zero() and ProblemBase._find_max_param(), which together determine if an expression is zero within a tolerance.
  • Modifies ProblemBase._require_homogeneous() to use these new functions rather than only checking if an expression is exactly zero.

values.description:
This PR implements basic restarting capability in core.  It primarily consists of:

* A new 'load_state' method on the IVP solver, which takes a path to any merged analysis file, and an index specifying which local write from that file should be loaded (default: -1, the last write).  The file must contain a task for every field in the state, but works with arbitrary analysis layouts and changes in resolution.  The method returns the global write number and timestep of the loaded state, which can be used to continue analysis and time stepping.

* Changes to the FileHandler so that it saves the timstep at each write, and allows the user to specify the starting index for the set and write numbers, to prevent restarted-analysis from clobbering original analysis.

* A restart example script for the 2D Rayleigh Benard IVP, that will pick up from the end of the original example script without clobbering its output.
values.title: Basic restarting capability & example

summary.raw:
This PR implements basic restarting capability in core.  It primarily consists of:

* A new 'load_state' method on the IVP solver, which takes a path to any merged analysis file, and an index specifying which local write from that file should be loaded (default: -1, the last write).  The file must contain a task for every field in the state, but works with arbitrary analysis layouts and changes in resolution.  The method returns the global write number and timestep of the loaded state, which can be used to continue analysis and time stepping.

* Changes to the FileHandler so that it saves the timstep at each write, and allows the user to specify the starting index for the set and write numbers, to prevent restarted-analysis from clobbering original analysis.

* A restart example script for the 2D Rayleigh Benard IVP, that will pick up from the end of the original example script without clobbering its output.
summary.html:
This PR implements basic restarting capability in core. It primarily consists of:

  • A new 'load_state' method on the IVP solver, which takes a path to any merged analysis file, and an index specifying which local write from that file should be loaded (default: -1, the last write). The file must contain a task for every field in the state, but works with arbitrary analysis layouts and changes in resolution. The method returns the global write number and timestep of the loaded state, which can be used to continue analysis and time stepping.

  • Changes to the FileHandler so that it saves the timstep at each write, and allows the user to specify the starting index for the set and write numbers, to prevent restarted-analysis from clobbering original analysis.

  • A restart example script for the 2D Rayleigh Benard IVP, that will pick up from the end of the original example script without clobbering its output.

values.description:
Introduce a very simple API for checkpointing, based on Ben's original ideas. A `Checkpoint` object creates a simple `FileHandler` called checkpoint that writes the state to a separate file each time it is evaluated. An example script, `examples/ivp/busse_annulus/busse.py`, shows how to use this. There is a simple helper function that allows you to pick up all of your other analysis files where they left off.

Known Issues
--------------------
* if the restart is from a previous time, analysis files will have two copies of all repeated timesteps. This does not present any particular challenge to the user, but it could be cleaned up in the future.
values.title: Simple Checkpointing mechanism

summary.raw:
Introduce a very simple API for checkpointing, based on Ben's original ideas. A `Checkpoint` object creates a simple `FileHandler` called checkpoint that writes the state to a separate file each time it is evaluated. An example script, `examples/ivp/busse_annulus/busse.py`, shows how to use this. There is a simple helper function that allows you to pick up all of your other analysis files where they left off.

Known Issues
--------------------
* if the restart is from a previous time, analysis files will have two copies of all repeated timesteps. This does not present any particular challenge to the user, but it could be cleaned up in the future.
summary.html:
Introduce a very simple API for checkpointing, based on Ben's original ideas. A Checkpoint object creates a simple FileHandler called checkpoint that writes the state to a separate file each time it is evaluated. An example script, examples/ivp/busse_annulus/busse.py, shows how to use this. There is a simple helper function that allows you to pick up all of your other analysis files where they left off.

Known Issues

  • if the restart is from a previous time, analysis files will have two copies of all repeated timesteps. This does not present any particular challenge to the user, but it could be cleaned up in the future.

values.description:
Adds an MPI transpose using alltoall instead of alltoallv, which may be more optimized in some MPI implementations.

Also adds some logic to make better use of grouped transposes after RHS evaluation.

Also adds some logic to make better use of grouped transposes after RHS evaluation.

values.description: This PR is a small but significant change to the eigenvalue solver. It moves both the eigenvalues and eigenvectors into numpy MaskedArrays, which allow the NaN eigenvalues to be skipped. They are still in the array, but normal slicing operations will not access them. See [http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.1/reference/maskedarray.generic.html](Masked Array docs) for more details.
values.title: Mask eigenvectors and eigenvalues to hide NaN values

summary.raw: This PR is a small but significant change to the eigenvalue solver. It moves both the eigenvalues and eigenvectors into numpy MaskedArrays, which allow the NaN eigenvalues to be skipped. They are still in the array, but normal slicing operations will not access them. See [http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.1/reference/maskedarray.generic.html](Masked Array docs) for more details.
summary.html: This PR is a small but significant change to the eigenvalue solver. It moves both the eigenvalues and eigenvectors into numpy MaskedArrays, which allow the NaN eigenvalues to be skipped. They are still in the array, but normal slicing operations will not access them. See http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.1/reference/maskedarray.generic.html for more details.

values.description:
This pull request primarily adds a scipy-based targeted sparse eigenvalue solver to `tools.sparse`, and adds a corresponding `solve_sparse` method to `EigenvalueSolver`.  The original `solve` method has been renamed to `solve_dense`, but I've left `solve` in as an alias to this, with a deprecation warning, for backwards compatibility.

The solver uses sparse routines to find a subset of the system's eigenmodes nearby a specified target eigenvalue.  It is based on scipy's ARPACK wrappers through scipy.sparse.linalg.eigs.

I've converted the EVP example computing RBC growth rates to the new sparse solver, and it now runs much faster.  I've also tested this solver against SLEPc/PETSc wrappers, and found that it matches or exceeds SLEPc performance for the RBC problem.
values.title: Add scipy-based sparse eigenvalue solver.

summary.raw:
This pull request primarily adds a scipy-based targeted sparse eigenvalue solver to `tools.sparse`, and adds a corresponding `solve_sparse` method to `EigenvalueSolver`.  The original `solve` method has been renamed to `solve_dense`, but I've left `solve` in as an alias to this, with a deprecation warning, for backwards compatibility.

The solver uses sparse routines to find a subset of the system's eigenmodes nearby a specified target eigenvalue.  It is based on scipy's ARPACK wrappers through scipy.sparse.linalg.eigs.

I've converted the EVP example computing RBC growth rates to the new sparse solver, and it now runs much faster.  I've also tested this solver against SLEPc/PETSc wrappers, and found that it matches or exceeds SLEPc performance for the RBC problem.
summary.html:
This pull request primarily adds a scipy-based targeted sparse eigenvalue solver to tools.sparse, and adds a corresponding solve_sparse method to EigenvalueSolver. The original solve method has been renamed to solve_dense, but I've left solve in as an alias to this, with a deprecation warning, for backwards compatibility.

The solver uses sparse routines to find a subset of the system's eigenmodes nearby a specified target eigenvalue. It is based on scipy's ARPACK wrappers through scipy.sparse.linalg.eigs.

I've converted the EVP example computing RBC growth rates to the new sparse solver, and it now runs much faster. I've also tested this solver against SLEPc/PETSc wrappers, and found that it matches or exceeds SLEPc performance for the RBC problem.
